commentBody: I did not know it was "Madama".... one of those things you must see a million times but your brain tells you it's Madame.

Finished in just under 8 minutes and scrambled over here to leave the first post. But someone else was already ahead of me! üòÖ

Oh well, that was a fun, quick, early-week puzzle. I appreciated the way the revealer brought all the theme clues together.

To say that "diaphanous" means LIGHT is kinda missing the point.  The reason "diaphanous" exists as a word is not because such a fabric is light, although it usually is.  It's because it's sheer, see-through, and thus a bit scandalous.  Garments that are light but opaque are not diaphanous; those that are diaphanous are only light as an aside.

This is not to say it fails as a clue for a crossword, but it's a little disingenous.

Mel OTT!

DUDE!

(My grandmother would be pleased.)

A breezy, fun Tuesday puzzle. Love the downward trajectory reflected in the construction. But, I particularly enjoyed the charming constructor notes. Congratulations on your terrific debut, Corry. My mother introduced me to puzzle solving too and she also enjoyed calling out the snicklefritzes in our family.
No GUTS no glory is a fitting start to this ode for Icarus.

Loved the theme, but perhaps the most trivia heavy crossword I have ever attempted. Even knowing a decent chunk of them, and getting several with crosses, it was much too tough for me.

Also, some nicknames/shorthand that weren't flagged as such? STENO and TUT

This was a really impressive debut for a number of reasons. A very charming theme that I enjoyed as a fellow lover of mythology. The revealer conveniently stacked right under the last clue. Four long extra down clues that were pretty interesting. Very little glue. I thought this was above average both in skill and solving enjoyment for a Tuesday. Well done!

I'm OVERTHEMOON for today's puzzle.

Today is the Harvest Moon, and the first supermoon of the year.

I'm wondering if the baseball fans on this forum got 58D, RUNS, without any crosses.

I consider myself a baseball fan, but it took me a second.  

By the way, speaking of baseball and to solvers from Toronto, the Blue Jays are in the process of utterly humiliating the Yankees.  I've never seen such hitting in the playoffs.  Has Toronto's offense been so prolific all season?

But...there's one more game, and we all know baseball can be fickle.  As a rooter for an American League team, you know what my thoughts on the Yanks.  They are terrifyingly resilient.

I always, even before I was a father, felt more for Daedalus than I did for the kid. And now as a father, I imagine that a father or two must have been involved in the origin of this myth, it's heavy with the tragedy of ignored fatherly advice, and of course lessons on hubris, greed, discontent, and that children traditionally ignore their parents' guidance at their peril -- but what's adolescence for if not that? None of which offers any consolation to a bereft father. It's not a myth that plays well these days. Have to say, this one has an abundance of familiar words and clues, old friends, it's good to see them again! Went downtown last night and saw a restored version of Charlie Chaplin's "The Gold Rush" (1925). What a masterpiece. In the scene I've linked below, he's invited some dance hall girls to have New Year's Eve dinner with him, there in the Klondike. They agree, including Georgia, the object of his love. Of course, they don't show up, and Charlie sadly lowers his head and finds himself dreaming of the dinner party that might have been, and how he'd entertain his guests... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4DLdMa98JdM
Poor ICARUS, who girlbossed too close to the sun

Fine debut, Mr. Cropper!

It felt slick, delicious, like swimming in a root beer float, rich and creamy.

I have no idea why I wrote that.  But I'll stand by it.

I‚Äôm going to try and scoop Mike for a change:
Did you study for the test on Icarus? No, I‚Äôm gonna wing it.
Very nice puzzle. And here is a link to Sebastian the Crab's song from The Little Mermaid. Some very nice fishy wordplay. https://youtu.be/c7UsTLZvPMg?si=XdHMOJCoOh0CuYXi
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/10/06/tuesday-october-7-2025/#ny Thanks for the fun, Mr. Cropper! Congratulations on the debut!
Here's a familiar tune (you may have to skip an ad): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tmfw17L_Deo

Seeing 54D (LATEX) reminded me of the Seinfeld episode in which George Costanza attempts to concoct a fictitious job application in order to keep collecting unemployment benefits. It fails miserably (and hilariously), as seen in this clip: - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_T35QhLx_KI

From the opening clue and answer (No GUTS, no glory!) to the ultimate fall of ICARUS, this was chef‚Äôs kiss perfection. The theme answers provided a perfect visual of the rise and fall. Even though Corry is NEW IN TOWN, I‚Äôm pretty sure we will be seeing more from him. Well done and congratulations on this exceptional debut üåü
Fast and fun.
Loved loved LOVED this theme! So clever!

DUDE! You may be NEW IN TOWN, but you‚Äôre a TOTAL NAT(ural).

ASLAN the lion, a great book by Jon Krakauer, and a shoutout to Marcel the monkey! What‚Äôs not to love (or AMOUR)? ‚ù§Ô∏è

Nice theme, pretty good puzzle. The fill was quite hard for me in places but I managed to deal with it in standard Tuesday time in the end. R/H/E was my biggest stumper today but crosses gave me the answer, and then I found an explanation of what it all meant in the column.

TOTAL for wreck beyond repair had me sigh. Poland is notorious for the cars on its roads being old and poorly maintained. The statistics are imperfect, because many people don't bother to notify the authorities when they scrap an auto but still, the average age of a car here is 18 years, and all parking lots are dotted all over with oil stains.

There was a time when a million old cars were imported into the country from the West per year. Many of them were written off as totaled in Germany. It was illegal to repair those wrecks over there, but unscrupulous Polish mechanics didn't care - they Frankensteined them back to life, or rather, undeath - and equally unscrupulous used car dealers sold them on, keeping the vehicles' history a secret. My ex's brother unwittingly bought such a Honda once. It cracked in half in a light collision. Only then did it turn out the front and back ends had come from two different wrecks that had been welded together...

Things are slowly improving now as prosperity increases, but it will be decades before our roads are rid of those deathtraps.

9D breaks the crossword rule of the clue matching the answer in grammatical number.

CANNOLI, being plural, cannot be an "Italian dessert menu staple." They are, however, Italian dessert menu staples.

Poor old Icarus - he came a cropper.

(Sorry, Corry, could not resist.)
Anyone else get a good smile when they had to erase SLAT in 5D only to put it back in at 62A?
Fun puzzle, thanks. And also a nice debut. Well done.
I enjoyed today's puzzle, or, I guess it's tomorrow's puzzle, but I'm not going to bother to say much more it's everything I say lately is inexplicably squashed by the powers that be....
Pretty tough fill for a Tuesday, though I‚Äôm not complaining! Was nice to get a little workout so early in the week.
A Tuesday tuffy for sure. A few too many proper nouns for this slow solver. LATH seems a bit esoteric, but it's always fun to learn a new word!
The theme made me smile when I got to 61A. I didn‚Äôt love all the clues but I did like the theme.

Nice debut, Corry,

Hope to see more from you. Got through this a bit faster than my average, Thought I'd just start it on my phone, only to find that I finished it before I got a chance to get to the computer.

Good puzzle, and thanks!
I‚Äôm surprised that this was Corry‚Äôs first puzzle for the NYT , a nice balance of challenging but fun for a Tuesday.  Looking forward to more.

An enjoyable puzzle, and I particularly enjoyed how the long entries were past of a specific story, rather than the more general themes I was thinking of during the solve. I'm also among those who had "slat" incorrectly entered in the top 3rd, and then chuckled when it appeared again in the middle third.

I was a little bit gutted to find that 25A wasn‚Äôt neep but ROOT. In Scotland, neep and turnip are synonymous* names for rutabaga, and for a moment it was thrilling to see this recognised in the NYT! Alas. It would‚Äôve been fitting for October, time to start gutting your neeps for jack o‚Äôlanterns, the harder to carve and more horrifying precursor to the pumpkin version.

*Yes, I know this doesn‚Äôt track to botanical nomenclature, don‚Äôt come at me

I am familiar with the comments forum of the spelling bee, but did not know this one existed!  I, too, had a problem with cannoli, but not because it is a plural. Doesn‚Äôt the ‚Äúa‚Äù turn ‚ÄúMadame Butterfly ‚Äú into ‚ÄúMadama Butterfly‚Äù? What am I missing? Thanks!
Lovely, fun debut, Professor!
Sorry, folks, just educated myself - I had no remote idea Madama was also correct. Really wondered about that! üòâ
Simply delightful!

Excellent debut, Corry.

Keep them coming!

Almost made it through without peeking, peaking or Peking! Only looking up stuff to check my spellings. Getting better all the time.
Hey bartender, I'm buyin' this round! Make mine a 42D Mockingbird!   (Dan Hicks: coolest laid-back troubadour there ever was!)
Delightful debut. Thank you.
The TESCO section slowed me down for a bit. Maybe the Brits who come here to complain about too many Americanisms in an American crossword puzzle will be temporarily placated.

One of Crosslanidia‚Äôs golden moments is when you uncover the revealer, and what connects the theme answers suddenly not only clicks, but is amazing.

I fell into in a state of wonder for a precious moment after filling in ICARUS, seeing his story told so ingeniously.  Ever so briefly the world stopped and I bathed, jaw dropped, in a euphoric wow.  

When a puzzle does that, I don‚Äôt care how easy or hard it was ‚Äì it was very, very well worth doing.  

Then I noticed more: 
‚Ä¢	Beautiful answers ‚Äì LILAC, LAMINA, ONYX.  
‚Ä¢	A theme based not just on the first or last word of its answers, but of the entire answer.  
‚Ä¢	An uber-rare-in-crosswords six-letter semordnilap (LAMINA). 
‚Ä¢	Theme echoes ‚Äì ORCA and UBOAT to go with UNDER THE SEA, LAVA and ROOT going with DOWN TO EARTH, and LIGHT near DAY IN THE SUN.

DAY IN THE SUN indeed, Corry ‚Äì what a splendid Times debut!  I eagerly hope for more ‚Äì thank you for a most memorable puzzle!

Nice Tuesday puzzle. Typical workout for me and I didn't grasp the theme until I worked out the reveal, but that was a nice 'aha' moment. And... must confess that with my poor memory I needed a couple of theme answers before I finally kind of remembered the connection to ICARUS. Fun puzzle find today - a Sunday from November 14, 1999 by Lloyd E. Pollet with the title: Stars "R" us. A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Actor getting bad press?" HENRYWRINKLER "Actress who's cold?" JODIEFROSTER And some other theme answers: JACKPARLANCE DEBRAWRINGER WESLEYSNIPERS PHOEBECRATES VIRGINIAMAYOR And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/14/1999&g=30&d=A ....
Great theme and well done on your debut.

Mus√©e des Beaux Arts
By W. H. Auden

December 1938
About suffering they were never wrong,
The Old Masters: how well they understood
Its human position; how it takes place
While someone else is eating or opening a window or just walking dully along

How, when the aged are reverently, passionately waiting
For the miraculous birth, there always must be
Children who did not specially want it to happen, skating
On a pond at the edge of the wood:
They never forgot
That even the dreadful martyrdom must run its course
Anyhow in a corner, some untidy spot
Where the dogs go on with their doggy life and the torturer's horse
Scratches its innocent behind on a tree.

In Brueghel's Icarus, for instance: how everything turns away
Quite leisurely from the disaster; the ploughman may
Have heard the splash, the forsaken cry, 
But for him it was not an important failure; the sun shone
As it had to on the white legs disappearing into the green
Water; and the expensive delicate ship that must have seen
Something amazing, a boy falling out of the sky,
Had somewhere to get to and sailed calmly on.

It‚Äôs funny how often I get inspiration for a meal idea from the crossword puzzle. 
Have *you* ever slung a sushi seaweed hash?
Nor I. But tonight I‚Äôll give it a try, caution be darned*.


*except when it comes to emus.

Entered MADAME instead of MADAMA, and didn't catch my mistake in time. Shouldn't have left the CENNOLI.

Defeated by a Tuesday puzzle. Sigh. 

Congratulations on the debut!

Ah, how Ayn Rand hated the myth of Icarus! The poor fellow dared to aspire, and he paid for it with his life. The universe itself must be a collectivist second-hander!

This is a fine debut puzzle, and just right for a Tuesday.

Oh no! This is not the puzzle I‚Äôd have thought my streak would succumb to, but (as a non-native speaker who started speaking English well into high school) the NW corner bested me. A combination of not being too acquainted with Shakespeare, not having heard of Fiddler on the Roof ever before, and being unfamiliar with ‚ÄúDAY‚Äù IN THE SUN doomed me (Time? Sure. Bask? Absolutely. DAY?? I couldn‚Äôt imagine Icarus spent more than a few minutes in it, with how close to it he got!). In retrospect, I should have easily picked up GILDS ‚Äî then, I could have inferred LOVE and probably cinched this thing. 

But listen, rambling aside, my educational deficiencies aren‚Äôt the puzzle‚Äôs fault. It was a delight. Though perfectly average on the difficulty scale, it was much richer and less prosaic than your regular Tuesday. Fantastic debut!

My book group likes to tease me about loving every book I read (which is absolutely not true, but years of running book discussions for surly teenagers trained me to tease out the positive). 

This always makes me self conscious about coming here to declare that I loved a puzzle, but I loved this puzzle! Terrific debut!

I loved yesterday‚Äôs too. I am who I am.

Hmm...could we say ICARUS "came a-cropper"?? Is Corry having a little fun with that?  Charlotte the Kitty seems to think she has an answer to that--she has joined me to be helpful.  That, or it's just that the floor is chilly and my lap is warm.

In these parts, nobody asks if you are NEW IN TOWN; they say, "You ain't from around here, are ya?"  (I try to beat them to it with "We're NEW here."  Back in Arkansas (where they ask the same question) I joined the NEW-comers Club.  When I asked one lady how long she had been a member, her response was, "Twenty years."  

I need to go change out of my walking clothes.  If I was constructing a crossword, I'd try to think of all the ways to say HOT AND HUMID.
A very fine debut indeed.  Many thanks.
Hats off to the constructor's mom: snicklefritz is given the day in the sun it needs; that's a jewel of a word there, rarer than the finest onyx.
Congratulations on the debut! Thanks for the fond memories of falling in love with playing Kid Icarus on my Nintendo Entertainment System as a young lad.

Congratulations on the debut!  I took your French 340 class in Winter 2006 and have many fond memories of your class, like the time you sold advertising space on your shirt and the news came to class.  Loved the Moliere reference!
Great job, Professeur. I liked this puzzle a lot.
Excellent debut, Professor Cropper!  Any relation to the great Steve Cropper?

A lovely debut!

I've always loved Greek mythology, so this puzzle was super fun.

Thanks, all, for helping me with ‚ÄúMadama‚Äù vs ‚ÄúMadame‚Äù.  Also, for being kind about it, which does not always happen with the spelling bee‚Ä¶
   BTW, don‚Äôt you just love it when some word/phrase/expression you‚Äôve known for years and years turns out to be incorrect? ü§™
Excellent theme and so clever!

**One Second** off my best time, but I take it as a record, because my previous Tuesday best resulted from re-entering an entire puzzle due to a glitch. It's been tough to beat that illicitly-if-innocently-attained time. A great puzzle, and I loved the evocative theme.
Shaved 8 seconds off of my Tuesday best on this gem! Thanks for the fun!
La Divina: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lk-cRaIHcLI&list=RDlk-cRaIHcLI&start_radio=1

MADAMA, I AM ADAM , or, as I like to say in Spain, DAMA, I AM AD.

Incredible theme! 




(I miss Saigon)
So much fun! Thanks, Corry! Happy Tuesday, y‚Äôall!
For the longest time I had IN_TI_ATE for 10D, and just couldn't see past wanting it to be 'Initiate'

So why isn't the opera called, "Madama Farfala?" And isn't the geisha's name Cho Cho? Someone is cheating here, and I think it's Puccini, not the constructor. I don't really follow opera; my tastes run more towards Iron Maiden, so here's an appropriate cut from "Piece of Mind": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X9oGkvpkefg I just learned that the new Prime Minister of Japan is a huge fan of the band, and once played drums in a metal band herself.
Wow, this was just a good, solid puzzle, with everything interesting and no garbage. Enjoyed from start to finish. Thank you, Corry Cropper! More, please!
I liked the theme but didnt appreciate some of the clues approaching natick level.  An overreliance on specific foreign words always annoys me a bit and feels cheaper.  Enjoyed most of this tho

Just finished the Sunday puzzle*.  Better late than never, I guess.  I thought it was going to be a breeze of a puzzle after filling in the NW corner without delay, but it seemed the further I went the harder it got.  11% slower than average.

*Even though I have not done Monday's or today's puzzle, no gold star awarded for Sunday.  It would be nice if the software was modified to award the gold star as long as a puzzle is done in sequence.  Not that I care about streaks, but for those who do, then they could go on vacation or whatever and be comforted by knowing they could pick up where they left off when they got back.
SALT LAKE CITY MENTIONED RAHHHH üó£Ô∏èüó£Ô∏èüó£Ô∏è
TEVYE / AMOUR / MADAMA / NORI / LAMINA / ASLAN / TESCO / ETNA / IDEE... rather ridiculous for a Tuesday. another round of Jeopardy!

Wow, pretty Saturdayish for a Tuesday‚Ä¶ truthfully, I don‚Äôt know if there‚Äôs ever been a puzzle with so many words I have either never heard of or very seldom heard used.

This is one of those puzzles by a new constructor that wants to show the world how clever they are by inserting words that no one uses with poor clues.

And one more puzzle find. Found this one because one of the answers in my earlier puzzle search had also appeared in this one. Anyway - A Wednesday from February 17, 2016 by Kyle Mahowald. Anyway - theme answers in that one: EDWARDSNOWEDIN JODIEFROSTER CURTCHILLING BARRYCOLDWATER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/17/2016&g=26&d=A ...

Just a quick de-cloaking to strut about and pump my chest and announce that I reached a 1000-game streak today. 

I never cared about streaks at all until someone pointed out that if you miss a day or three, as long as you complete the older puzzle(s) before the newer one(s), your streak is maintained. 

Sadly, this meant I started to care about streaks. (Whenever I traveled my streak would get broken so I didn't care...)

I am not sure my life has improved now that I care about my streak. I'm not about to break it, though!

So, a hearty "thank you" and an equally hearty "damn you!" to whoever it was who turned me on to this little bit of streak strategy.

I loved this crossword! It was just really rich with a satisfying and lovely fill. And I appreciated the poetic and the ever-so-slightly mournful tone of the theme. Thanks for this one. I found it deeply satisfying to solve. (Oh and thanks for teaching me the word "snicklefritz"! It's a great word that I will be sure to start using!)

Oooohh - one more late puzzle find. NEVER seen another one like this. Anyway - a Thursday from November 4, 2004 by the great Elizabeth C. Gorski. A five square crossing answer in the very middle of the puzzle was five rebus squares, which were: (DUCK)(DUCK)(DUCK)(DUCK)(DUCK) Some of the down crossing answers on that were: WOODDUCK ODDDUCK DUCKING and DUCKSOUP But there was a 15 letter down answer crossing the very middle square in that streak. And it was: GETONESDUCKSINAROW Thought that was just amazing. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/4/2004&g=39&d=A ....

Great debut puzzle, Corry Cropper! Very clever theme, and I was also touched by your memory of your mother doing crosswords. I do believe my children and grandchildren are following suit, though I might be giving myself too much credit. They all do puzzles‚Äîexcept the 2 and 4 year old grands. And of course they do age appropriate puzzles they can put together with their hands. I don‚Äôt know what I would do without all my daily NYT puzzles. 
And thanks for your column, Sam. I always look forward to your extra info and your sense of humor. I too had trouble with the sports clue at 58D. I‚Äôm just not sports savvy, although I have no trouble with Mel OTT, as he pops up so often in xwords. 
Thanks to the whole team üòäüëèüèª

Striker posted this story about Andrea Carla Michaels a ways down and I'm reposting so it's more visible. https://brokeassstuart.com/p/meet-sf-s-pizza-lady-fighting-waste-while-feeding-the-hungry?utm_campaign=feed&utm_medium=referral&utm_source=later-linkinbio&fbclid=PAQ0xDSwNSDaRleHRuA2FlbQIxMQABp3S_WT0GJOXXeQtphlqgXk-1gCm8ToAc-E6K4W2V-sWR6dwCYIRG3UZhshzk_aem_v9TkzL0it6yTew_s_xkTZg Striker's link is shorter, so you may need to look for it if mine won't open for you.
A few too many naticks and proper nouns but this was a fun puzzle!

Classic malapop for me today, and I'm thinking, I'm not alone.

A malapop, btw, is a crossword term, like natick.  It was coined by constructor Andrea Carla Michaels, and is when you place an answer down, but then take it out because it doesn't work with the crosses ... then, later, that very answer you took out turns out to be the right answer somewhere else in the grid.

My malapop was entering SLAT for [Wood strip], taking it out because it was supposed to be LATH, then, sure enough, SLAT got into the grid elsewhere for [Venetian blind component].

Anyone else do the same?

What an utterly delightful debut! I‚Äôll be looking out for more of your puzzles.

Now I‚Äôm off to go learn what snicklefritz means!
One of my favorites! Wonderful puzzle.
Am I the only one who thought R/H/E had to mean something like Run, Hide, Escape? Maybe I just spend too much time with school teachers.

What a great theme. I couldn't help but think of the great landscape painting by Bruegel the Elder depicting the fall of Icarus. Icarus makes a relatively small cameo; you can see his legs flailing in the lower right corner, UNDERTHESEA. If you didn't look close enough, you might have thought he disappeared INTOTHINAIR. Meanwhile the farmer in the foreground plows away oblivious, and the shepherd casts his eyes skyward, enjoying his DAYINTHESUN
One of my favorite stories from Greek mythology. Good puzzle!
Bravo Corry!  Look forwad to more from you.

Impressive debut, Corry - looking forward to seeing more from you!  

Like many solvers today, I originally had MADAMe/CeNNOLI, but with CANNOLI being my favorite treat from Boston's North End, I eventually corrected my sweet Italian error.
A great debut and a fun Tuesday puzzle! I temporarily had the same error as several other folks when I entered "MADAME." Glad I'm not the only one!
Adding my comment to the group: Madama is NOT correct.
Excellent debut Corry!
Did not care for this puzzle. It insists upon itself.

@Richard
I also entered MADAMe and had to fix it on the crossings. But it makes sense if that opera is Italian, not French ü§ì

@Richard

Take the Madama.
Leave the Cannoli.

üòâ

@Richard coincidentally I just bought a poster for my collection of vintage advertisements - the one for the production of MADAMA Butterfly at La Scala in Milan.  I thought at first it was that way because the opera was performed in Italy.  I left it blank to let the crosses decide.
@Richard Hoping this inspires an Italian restaurant to create a dessert called cennoli (which apparently means "nod to them").

@Richard

I remembered MADAMA from school. We once discussed interactions between Polish and foreign languages, and how our ancestors dealt with gendered nouns and transcription in such cases. MADAMA BUTTERFLY was given as an example. It stuck.
Steve, Or definition 3? (Perhaps odd for a Tuesday.) https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diaphanous
@Steve L. ‚ÄúSheer‚Äù has the same number of letters as LIGHT, but didn‚Äôt fit the crosses.

@Steve L
I was going to say the same thing.  The defining attribute of something diaphanous is translucent.  Many things can be defined as light that are not at all diaphanous.  And so, I initially resisted filling in "LIGHT".

@Barry Ancona
But all 3 of those definitions carry the implication of something sheer or insubstantial.  As a clue, it's a miss, imo.

@Steve L

Hand up for "sheer."

@DW
Perhaps the clue might‚Äôve been ‚Äúwhat gets through a diaphanous garment‚Äù!
  But this was a fun, quick Tuesday puzzle. 

Thanks Corry!

@Steve L

I know what you mean - I personally also didn't like this clue/answer combo. All diaphanous materials are indeed light, so, as you say, the clue doesn't fail. Yet I still think it was a bad one.

@Steve L
Sheer was my first guess.  I was pretty proud of myself for coming up with it, but, alas, the crosses proved me wrong.

DW,

Insubstantial = light.

@Steve L
And yet here you are misusing the word "disingenuous," which means "lacking in candor" or "calculating." The implication that the constructor and editors used the incorrect word on purpose in order to trick people is ludicrous.

@Barry Ancona

She was a Giants fan, huh?  From the days when NY had *three* teams?

@Francis

Off Topic here.  My  "proofreading" for a typo yesterday was based on personal experience of entering a 4 via numeric pad mistakenly for a 1 on more than a couple of occasions.

It also produced a reasonable -22F for winter in Milwaukee rather than -55.

Unfortunately, I overlooked the much more likely explanation that the OP was thinking of windchill, not temperature. This still bothers me.

Francis,

I was a Yankees fan in the days when NY had three teams. My grandmother had drinks with Mel OTT in a speak -- a bit before my time.

@Al  in Pittsburgh your thought that it was my typo was completely reasonable! I would have thought the same had I not experienced it myself üòÇü•∂ Your explanation for my statement was on point, it just happened to not be correct this particular time. All good üëçüèº

@Barry Ancona

That's pretty cool!

@Seb

I wonder if someone can explain this to me:  I often read that there's too much "trivia" in these puzzles.

Question 1:  Which did you consider trivial?  I can imagine virtually anything being trivial.  I once said to a Indian (sub continent) grad student, that in the cosmic scale, something or other was trivial.  He responded in the the cosmic scale, the cosmos is trivial.

Question 2:  Do you really think that puzzles 20, 30, 40 years ago has *less* trivia?  I remember so many tiny rivers and minor Shakespeare characters back then.  Wasn't that trivia?  Is it possible for a crossword to be anything other than trivia?

@Francis

Trivia is tricky to define. What is "common" knowledge varies greatly depending on age, gender, region and background. In this context though, I'm generally referring to proper nouns, answers that can't be solved through knowledge of word structure. 

For example, I did not know the word APSES until today. However, I was able to solve it because I knew how to make a plural of a word ending in s. Contrast to TEVYE, a proper noun I have never encountered. Unless I solved it entirely through crosses (which I could not), there was simply no way for me to progress.

Part of the joy of crosswords for me is word structure, and proper nouns just don't follow the same structural rules. There's no satisfying way to solve for a proper noun, to get a eureka moment where a hidden phrase all becomes clear. Either you know the trivia and get it instantly or you don't and must rely on crosses. I find that unsatisfying.

I have no idea about crosswords before I was born. I'm sure they had trivia back then too, and never meant to imply there had been a change over time. I've been solving for about a year and was just sharing my personal experience of trivia in crosswords.

@Seb

Fair enough!

@Francis

I was once attacked on this board for referring to some American proper names as trivia. But to me, they were. I consider all factual knowledge that's unessential to my life as it is trivial. And I agree with Seb - there is no satisfying way to solve unknown trivia. There simply is no "Aha!" moment. I also don't pretend I'm learning things from crossword trivia. What's the point of remembering US tv networks, names of journalists, etc.? Whether I know this stuff or look it up, the result for the crossword is the same.
@Seb  I could be wrong, but I think APSES is the plural of apse, a pretty common crossword entry, and not a word that ends with S.

@Francis
Compared to some crosswords, there is 'trivia' in the NYT, but I'm used to it now. I am still frustrated by brand names, like yesterday's TEVA.

What I used to call trivia I now think of as NYT crossword 'stuff' - Mel OTT, PSAT, IHOP, TSA, RBI, all those initials. I would still prefer it if it wasn't there, and all the clues had some thought behind them, but as they say in the US "It's not gonna happen."

Of course, I am tripped up by cultural differences. 
Like, what is a family room? Is it different from the living room? Is there something special about the TV in there? Also, a den (in a house) - is that like a study? 

It is a bit like learning a new language.

@Jane Wheelaghan

To me, a family room is like a living room, but if you have a big enough house, your living room is where you entertain guests, and ironically, the family room is where you do your living. 

Usually, the living room is situated near the front entrance, while the family room is off to the side or in the basement. 

Often, there‚Äôs a TV in the family room, but not in the living room. So some people refer to this room as a TV room. But if the electronics get too fancy, it can be called a media room, which is more like a home theater, which is to say it is purpose-built. 

A den is just another name for a family room.

@Seb APSE is not trivia; it's crosswordese (in fact it'sthe very first example listed on the Wikipedia article on crosswordese). I get the feeling that it appears rougly every other week in the NYT crossword. 

Like someone else said, it's like learning a new language.

@Steve L
Thanks again.
This is strangely similar to what used to be the custom in the UK some years ago. Many families had a "front room" near the front entrance, which was kept immaculate, with the best furniture and china ornaments etc and it was only for sitting with visitors, even if you hardly ever had visitors. Maybe used for a birthday or at Christmas.

The fire was only lit when there were visitors, (when every room had a coal fire) and so it was usually freezing cold.

Crofter cottages used to be 2 rooms, called the "but and ben", where "but" was the kitchen area and "ben" a sitting room. When I was a child, people would still say "Come ben the hoose" or "Come ben" even when living in a more modern house or flat. I don't know if this is used by young people today!

@Steve L, agree with all, except for den. Not the same as family room at all, but more like a study or, in today‚Äôs parlance, a home office. Imagine Ward Cleaver in the 50s, coming home to June, Wally, and the Beaver and retiring to his den to read the evening newspaper. Fairly archaic and quaint these days.  (My apologies to all Non-Americans and Americans under the age of 50 for the US-centric Boomer example, but it‚Äôs all I got.j

@Deri Note that my post began with the words "To me..." The Wikipedia article indicates that both our ideas of what a den is can be considered accurate. I think it might be an urban vs. suburban difference. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Den_(room) Where I've lived, we've used "family room" and "den" interchangeably; the room we referred to had a large TV, a wall of bookshelves, and a small desk in it.

@Seb

So I wouldn‚Äôt say there was no trivia, just that it didn‚Äôt seem trivia heavy. TEVYE could certainly be considered trivia, although it‚Äôs fair game not only as a musical reference but a literary reference as well, and the crosses are not unreasonable for a Tuesday.

@Jane Wheelaghan

I think there are differences in room names regionally in the US and they may have also changed in time. When I was growing up and we had one main room I would just have called it the living room, and never really used the term family room. Later we had a family room where you hung out most of the time and watched TV, and a living room mainly for meeting guests‚Äîwhat some would call a parlor. Odd that you no longer ‚Äúlived‚Äù in a living room. As for den, I think of that as synonymous with study now, but honestly some people might think of a den as the same as family room, or else a hang out room for certain members of the family, maybe like a teen area or a place where some family members can pursue hobbies.

@SP

@Katy
There are so many places in CrossWorld where it is wise to leave a blank space and wait.  If you are unsure of the gender of a noun, don't enter the vowel(s) right away.  If an entry might be either Where or There, skip the first letter.  Etc.  Or write your guesses in the margin if you are a Pen and Paper Person.

Shakespeare's Sonnet 116, probably his most famous, and a favorite of mine among all poetry:

Let me not to the marriage of true minds
Admit impediments; love is not love
Which alters when it alteration finds,
Or bends with the remover to remove.
O no, it is an ever-fix√®d mark
That looks on tempests and is never shaken;
It is the star to every wand'ring bark
Whose worth's unknown, although his height be taken.
Love's not time's fool, though rosy lips and cheeks
Within his bending sickle's compass come.
Love alters not with his brief hours and weeks,
But bears it out even to the edge of doom:
If this be error and upon me proved,
I never writ, nor no man ever loved.

I filled in MADAM_, waited for the crosses, and was happily surprised when the A filled in.

Of course, even veteran operaphiles say "Madame Butterfly" in casual speech--although oddly no one says "Mrs. Butterfly, which would also make sense, seeing that she's the wife of an American.

But Italian opera is full of titles like this: Donizetti's *Anna Bolena* and *Lucia di Lammermoor* (Walter Scott's Lucy of Lammermoor), and Puccini's *La Faniculla del West*--the "Girl of the (Golden) West"--spring to mind.

The graphic novelist (?!) Edward Gorey did a good parody of this in his stories "The Gilded Bat" (ballet) and "The Blue Aspic" (opera, including the moving *Lizzia Bordena*).

Fiddler on the Roof (musical and movie)
French: common word in crosswords, elsewhere
Opera, popular, with many adaptations since 1898,
   including plays movies, and books. Started as a play
   named Madame Butterfly, on which the opera was based
Seaweed option at many Japanese/sushi restaurants
Scientific term: spinal surgery, vehicle airflow, etc.
Symbol of Christ in C. S. Lewis's Narnia series
British grocery store, name not well known in US
Famous Italian volcano
French: term for preoccupation; not seen often

While some of these are not common, I've encountered all of these terms, most of them more than once, and not only in crosswords. I would not have called this anything close to a Jeopardy-level quiz, although it also had some older words not commonly used like GILDS or LATH, or even STENO. In any case, the crossings were quite fair, and helped me in several spots as I cruised through this in about two-thirds of my usual time.

@CQ
Congratulations!
I reached a 1000 day streak in summer of 2023, celebrated by taking a two-night backpacking trip, and purposely breaking it. Now I regret that--I took my phone with me, so I could use it as a camera, but also had good enough reception, and enough battery endurance, to be able to call home to check in both evenings; so, in fact, I could have done the puzzle that day.

Then, in 2024, I broke it again, purposely broke it, as an act of solidarity with striking journalists (remember that?)--in retrospect, once again felt it was a stupid move.

Now my streak is 300 and change. Pfft!

Should we care about streaks? In the long run, probably not; but David Connell (whose streak should be approaching 3000 by now) once remarked that every day his streak is maintained is proof to himself that he is still among the living--and who are we to question that reasoning?

@Coco Amar except the Puccini opera is Madama Butterfly.

@Coco Amar

There was a play, based on a book, both named Madame Butterfly. Puccini saw the play, wrote the opera, and debuted it in 1898, when it flopped. He re-wrote it and that version premiered in 1904 and was a hit, and has continued to be a hit. Since he was Italian, and the libretto is in Italian, he named the opera in Italian: MADAMA Butterfly. It has spawned plays, musicals, and movies.
